Posted By: ugotpauld (12/11/2010 3:26:35 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Everyone complaining about having "to waste their second turn leveling up Student of Warfare" sound ridiculous to me. Would you rather have a solid 3/3 first striker who can attack on turn 2 or have a "stronger" creature come into play, but most likely have summoning sickness?  
  
And the thing about level up creatures-- you don't HAVE to level them up if you don't want to. If you have better cards in your hand that you'd rather use, pay the mana for them instead. The leveling up is nice because as long as the creature's on the field, you can level it up. If you choose not to level it up now, you can do so later and make them stronger. And if the cards in your hand wouldn't benefit you at the moment or you have insufficient mana to play them, you can always just tap the mana and level up rather than having them sit there and do nothing for your turn.  
  
I'm not an avid fan of level up creatures-- this is probably one of the few very usable ones out there. But a solution for those who gripe ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: iSlapTrees (1/10/2011 11:23:40 AM)

posts.post_content:
Personally, I love this card. She is a powerful one mana card, something I appreciate, as I don't like having to wait for five mana to come around to have removal worthy threats on the board. Three damage turn two with one card is AMAZING. As others have pointed out, yes, she dies to removal. So does [Baneslayer Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Baneslayer Angel). That doesn't stop people for paying $35 for her. The really nice thing about levelers is that no matter what turn you get them, they're useful. A turn one [Elite Vanguard](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Elite Vanguard) is nice, but by turn seven, not as great. And, if you have something you'd prefer to play on turn two *you can do that instead*. Since level up isn't an echo cost or anything like that, you can chose to forgo that early three damage to play your [Honor of the Pure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Honor of the Pure), or other two drop card. The nice thing about level up is that it gives players options, and for the terminally mana screwed ways to deal damage.  
  
On the subject of the art: I th... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: Carnophage_4ever (11/7/2010 10:45:51 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Don't diss the level up mechanic, man. I think it's a fun and flavourful mechanic that has many cool applications. The Zendikar block has taken inspiration from RPGs like D&D before (in the Adventurer and Quest concepts) so I don't think it's strange that they would introduce levelers to the game. I believe these guys will add to the game rather than detract from it.  
  
This particular specimen is an awesome creature, since you can potentially have a 3/3 First Strike swinging on turn 2! As the game goes on, he'll remain relevant as a mana-sink for when you have no plays. Then, he becomes a 4/4 Double Strike late-game, which is quite amazing to be honest. I like levelers in general because they can remain relevant throughout the game, instead of being quick and dirty 1 or 2 drops that lose their place in the spotlight as soon as bigger creatures make their way onto the battlefield.
posts.html:

I believe these guys will add to the game rather than detract from it.

This particular specimen is an awesome creature, since you can potentially have a 3/3 First Strike swinging on turn 2! As the game goes on, he'll remain relevant as a mana-sink for when you have no plays. Then, he becomes a 4/4 Double Strike late-game, which is quite amazing to be honest. I like levelers in general because they can remain relevant throughout the game, instead of being quick and dirty 1 or 2 drops that lose their place in the spotlight as soon as bigger creatures make their way onto the battlefield.

Rating:

posts.post_content: People seem to forget that they made a card quite similar to this. [Figure of Destiny](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Figure of Destiny). Now while I'm not saying this is as good as Figure, it serves much the same purpose, particularly in the control matchups. Against control decks, this sort of creature is a real headache, because it's large enough to take decent chunks out of your life so they don't have to over-commit to the board. All they have to do is play land, swing, go. End of turn, level. Rinse repeat until it's a 4/4 Double Striker.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
This card is great for UW, GW, BW, and RW combos. People who are turned off by it's 7 counters are -once again- ignoramuses. You only pump this guy to 4/4 as a finisher.  
  
Tips on how to use this guy:  
  
Just level it up into a 3/3 first strike creature, it is a great attacker.   
  
Level it up into a 4/4 double strike creature but only as a finisher.  
  
Pair it with 1 [Knight Exemplar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Knight Exemplar) and this card is an indestructible threat.   
  
Pair it with 2 [Knight Exemplar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Knight Exemplar) and just go berserk with it.  
  
Works well with [Honor of the Pure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Honor of the Pure), [Ranger of Eos](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ranger of Eos), [Noble Hierarch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Noble Hierarch), [Birds of Paradise](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Birds of Paradise), and many others.
posts.html:
This card is great for UW, GW, BW, and RW combos. People who are turned off by it's 7 counters are -once again- ignoramuses. You only pump this guy to 4/4 as a finisher.

Tips on how to use this guy:

Just level it up into a 3/3 first strike creature, it is a great attacker.

Level it up into a 4/4 double strike creature but only as a finisher.

Pair it with 1 Knight Exemplar and this card is an indestructible threat.

Pair it with 2 Knight Exemplar and just go berserk with it.

Works well with Honor of the Pure, Ranger of Eos, Noble Hierarch, Birds of Paradise, and many others.

Posted By: redsoxftw (3/17/2011 8:00:48 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
*"yes, it dies to removal, as does 95%+ of other creatures out there. if you want to waste your removal spell on my one cmc creature go right ahead. the more threats 'worthy' of being removed you can put in your deck, the better."*   
   
A vast majority of time the "dies to removal argument" is nonsense. Levelers are one instance when the argument stands. If you've sunk mana into Student of Warfare, you've forsook other things you could have done with that mana. You've built yourself a threat with that mana, but once it's gone, so is all that effort; you've placed all your eggs in one basket and then lost them. Losing a leveled creature to a Terror (or whatever spell you like) can be a massive blow to your tempo. This is largely why none of the levelers have been popular in competitive play.
posts.html:
